Package com.deliburd.extrataskschedulers

Class StealingCallbackExecutor

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.concurrent.AbstractExecutorService
      • java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor
        • com.deliburd.extrataskschedulers.StealingCallbackExecutor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AutoShutdownExecutorService, CallbackExecutorService, StealingCallbackExecutorService, StealingExecutorService, Executor, ExecutorService
    public class StealingCallbackExecutor
extends ThreadPoolExecutor
implements StealingCallbackExecutorService, AutoShutdownExecutorService
    A ThreadPoolExecutor which has three main features added to it and the Future it returns, StealingCallbackFuture

    First, work can be stolen from this pool via StealingFuture.stealingGet() and its overload. A StealingCallbackFuture, which is a subinterface of StealingFuture and CallbackFuture, is returned from the submit methods provided in this class. Work stealing can be enabled or disabled through setWorkStealing(boolean) and canStealWork. When work is stolen, the queue is polled to see if there any work to be done. This is enabled by default. However, a cached thread pool created from the static utility class, StealingCallbackExecutors, will disable this feature by default because each task will start a new thread or use an existing idle thread, which means that in general no opportunities are provided for work stealing.

    Second, callbacks can be added to the StealingCallbackFutures returned in this class as it is a subinterface of CallbackFuture.

    Lastly, this thread pool can be made to automatically shut down on JVM shut down which is disabled by default. It can be enabled with addShutdownOnExit(boolean) and disabled with removeShutdownOnExit().

    Note: No interrupts will be sent to tasks actively executing that were stolen from the queue if shutdownNow() is called. Also beforeExecute(Thread, Runnable) and afterExecute(Runnable, Throwable) cannot be overridden because they cannot be properly called for stolen tasks to follow what is done in ThreadPoolExecutor.

    Author:
    DELIBURD
    See Also:
    StealingCallbackExecutors, StealingCallbackFuture

      • StealingCallbackExecutor

        public StealingCallbackExecutor​(int corePoolSize,
                                int maximumPoolSize,
                                long keepAliveTime,
                                TimeUnit unit,
                                boolean useSynchronousQueue)
        Creates a StealingCallbackExecutor with the given core pool size, maximum pool size, keep-alive time, and work queue.
        Parameters:
        corePoolSize - The core pool size. This must be 0 or larger.
        maximumPoolSize - The maximum pool size. This must be larger than or equal to corePoolSize.
        keepAliveTime - The keep-alive time of created threads. This must be larger than 0.
        unit - The unit that the keep-alive time is in. This cannot be null.
        useSynchronousQueue - True to use a SynchronousQueue. False to use a LinkedBlockingQueue.

    • Method Detail

      • stealTask

        protected Runnable stealTask()
        Steals a task from the work queue that the calling thread can run. Returns null if no task is available for this thread to run or work stealing is not enabled.
        Returns:
        A task from the work queue that the calling thread can run. Null if no task is available for this thread to run or work stealing is not enabled.

      • incrementCompletedStolenTaskCount

        protected void incrementCompletedStolenTaskCount()
        Increments the completed stolen task count. This is to used in StealingCallbackFutureTask when work is stolen and done.

      • incrementStolenWorkExecutorThreadCount

        protected void incrementStolenWorkExecutorThreadCount()

      • decrementStolenWorkExecutorThreadCount

        protected void decrementStolenWorkExecutorThreadCount()

      • getQueue

        public BlockingQueue<Runnable> getQueue()
        Returns the task queue of StealingCallbackFutures used by this executor. Access to the task queue is intended primarily for debugging and monitoring. This queue may be in active use. Retrieving the task queue does not prevent queued tasks from executing. Adding elements to this queue will result in undefined behavior.
        Overrides:
        getQueue in class ThreadPoolExecutor

        Returns:
